question_text: During the Yuan dynasty, which group of four literati painters became renowned for using ink wash landscapes to express personal feeling rather than serve the Mongol court, helping define the scholar-painting tradition?
correct_answer: The Four Masters of the Yuan: Huang Gongwang, Wu Zhen, Ni Zan, and Wang Meng
distractors: The Four Masters of the Yuan: Zhao Mengfu, Wu Zhen, Ni Zan, and Wang Meng
The Four Masters of the Song: Huang Gongwang, Wu Zhen, Ni Zan, and Wang Meng
The Four Masters of the Yuan: Huang Gongwang, Ma Yuan, Ni Zan, and Wang Meng

question_text: Which city in Jiangxi province, named after the reign title of Emperor Zhenzong around 1004 CE, became the largest center of Chinese porcelain production by the 14th century and is known as the "Porcelain Capital"?
correct_answer: Jingdezhen, famous for Qingbai ware, blue-and-white porcelain, and famille rose
distractors: Jingdezhen, famous for celadon ware, sancai glazed pottery, and famille rose
Longquan, famous for Qingbai ware, blue-and-white porcelain, and famille rose
Jingdezhen, famous for Qingbai ware, blue-and-white porcelain, and cloisonne enamel

question_text: Emperor Huizong of Song (r. 1100--1126) created a distinctive calligraphy style whose thin, angular strokes were compared to twisted gold filaments. What is this style called, and what were his primary painting subjects?
correct_answer: "Slender Gold" (Shoujinti) calligraphy; his primary painting subjects were birds and flowers
distractors: "Slender Gold" (Shoujinti) calligraphy; his primary painting subjects were landscapes and mountains
"Golden Inlaid" (Jincuodao) calligraphy; his primary painting subjects were birds and flowers
"Slender Gold" (Shoujinti) calligraphy; his primary painting subjects were court figures and horses

question_text: The Eight Eccentrics of Yangzhou were Qing dynasty painters known for rejecting orthodox styles in favor of expressive individualism. Which member, also called Zheng Banqiao, is among the most celebrated of this group?
correct_answer: Zheng Xie, known for bold paintings of bamboo, orchids, and rocks
distractors: Jin Nong, known for bold paintings of bamboo, orchids, and rocks
Zheng Xie, known for meticulous paintings of court ladies and gardens
Zheng Xie, known for bold paintings of horses, mountains, and rivers

question_text: Chan Buddhism, derived from the Sanskrit term $\textit{dhyana}$ meaning meditation, emphasizes direct insight into one's own Buddha-nature. By what names is this tradition known in Japan and Korea respectively?
correct_answer: Zen in Japan and Seon in Korea, both derived from the Chinese term Chan
distractors: Zen in Japan and Thien in Korea, both derived from the Chinese term Chan
Seon in Japan and Zen in Korea, both derived from the Chinese term Chan
Zen in Japan and Seon in Korea, both derived from the Sanskrit term Sutra

question_text: Sancai ("three-color") ceramics, most associated with the Tang dynasty, used lead-based glazes with metal oxide colorants. Which oxides produced the characteristic amber-brown and green colors in these wares?
correct_answer: Iron oxide for amber-brown and copper oxide for green, applied over a white clay body
distractors: Cobalt oxide for amber-brown and copper oxide for green, applied over a white clay body
Iron oxide for amber-brown and manganese oxide for green, applied over a white clay body
Iron oxide for amber-brown and copper oxide for green, applied over a red stoneware body
